author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the guidelines for auto-merging. Please make sure that you have read the [General registry README](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/blob/master/README.md) and the [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). The following guidelines were not met:

- Package name similar to 5 existing packages.
  1. Similar to Atom. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 1 is at or below cutoff of 2. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 1 between lowercased names is at or below cutoff of 1. Normalized visual distance 2.49 is at or below cutoff of 2.50.
  2. Similar to Atomix. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  3. Similar to Attrs. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  4. Similar to Actors. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.
  5. Similar to Automa. Damerau-Levenshtein distance 2 is at or below cutoff of 2.

Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

After you have fixed the AutoMerge issues, simple retrigger Registrator, which will automatically update this pull request. You do not need to change the version number in your `Project.toml` file (unless of course the AutoMerge issue is that you skipped a version number, in which case you should change the version number).

If you do not want to fix the AutoMerge issues, please post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have also read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

[noblock]

Regarding the similarity of the package name to previous packages, I would like to argue that the problem is small since Atom.jl refers to Github's abandoned editor and Atomix.jl is for atomic operations, whereas this package deals with actual atoms.

Since the Atom editor is not being developed, Atom.jl is unlikely to be widely developed and used going forward. 

That said, Atoms.jl feels like a very general name, but the package description feels like the package has a specific purpose. For example, there are other packages with names like https://github.com/Chemellia/AtomicGraphNets.jl (@DhairyaLGandhi). I think that a slightly longer and more descriptive name is preferable here.

Thanks for the suggestion, @MasonProtter. For the moment, `Atoms.jl` provides a Hartreeâ€“Fock solver for the ground state of the atom, which indeed works with orbitals. In the future, however, I foresee adding capabilities going beyond the independent-particle model, e.g. a full two-electron wavefunction for helium, etc., where the concept of orbitals doesn't really apply. Hence, I would not want to lock-in on the orbitals aspect.

For the same reason (i.e. my future plans of extensions), I _do_ feel that the package will be general enough to warrant the name `Atoms.jl` (have you noticed I'm really fond of it? ðŸ˜„), but I appreciate that other people may have differing ideas of what `Atoms.jl` would entail. How general do you think it should be @ViralBShah, for the name to be acceptable?

I'm thinking of `AtomicSystems.jl` as an alternative, but I'm not completely happy about it, because it could be interpreted as systems made of atoms (molecules or crystals, I suppose, but those I would have named `Molecules.jl` and `Crystals.jl`, in the same vein), but for this package I am targeting the ground and excited states (in the future, I have code for this that needs clean-up) of single atoms, along with property calculations such as polarizability, perturbation theory, etc. Another name could be `AtomicStructure.jl`, but that is also a misnomer, since I do not consider the internal structure of the nucleus. `ElectronicStructure.jl` would be _correct_, but promising too much since again, I do not consider molecules or crystals.

Soliciting some input from @antoine-levitt and @mortenpi.

Perhaps @rkurchin @mfherbst have some thoughts as well. 

Apart from my comment that the name should be somewhat more descriptive, since `Atoms` can mean so many things and is a short name, I don't have a strong view on how general it can be. It can be pretty general. If some of the folks pinged here feel Atoms.jl is a way to go, I am also happy to merge it. I just wanted to get a small discussion going on a potentially more descriptive name.

I have to agree that `Atoms` is a little too generic for something that calculates the electron structure of atoms (e.g. in the olden times it looks like there was an unregistered [Atoms.jl](https://github.com/libAtoms/Atoms.jl) that dealt with molecular dynamics).

I think that `AtomicStructure` could be a good name for this -- in my experience, atomic structure refers specifically to the electronic structure theory of atoms, and not the nuclear structure theory.

After discussing some more with @mortenpi, I think we are converging on `AtomicStructure.jl`, so if everybody would be happy with that name, I'll start the process of renaming the package in all places necessary ðŸ˜….
New PR: https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/65817 (I did not know if I could somehow update this one)
